SA'I URDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1906
LORD MILNER. i Lord Milner has received many flattering

proofs since his return to England of the regard in which he is held by his fellow-countrymen. They have not forgotten, and they will not forget, his inestimable services to the Empire, and they have testified their admiration by presenting him with an address, which both for the number and the quality of its signatures is without a parallel in political history. The paltry and spiteful attempt which was made to get the House of Com
mons to pass an oblique vote of censure upon - him simply excited the scorn of all honourable

men throughout the Empire, and we do not doubt that it helped to ensure the success of the address from the Cape Colony which was presented to Lord Milner last week An influential deputation came all the way from South Africa to assure him that twenty-five thousand signatories in the Cape Colony alone are true to the great principles for which he worked unflinchingly in face of the most formidable obstacles, those principles being "the gradual fusion of the white races of South Africa into one nation, and the retention of that nation as a permanent member of the British group of States." Sir Lewis Michell said that he had never found him other than "calm and collected and inflexibly resolute to see that by no act of his the British flag should be trailed in the dust." Lord Milner no longer holds any official position ; his influence consists solely of the weight which attaches to the opinions expressed in his speeches, and their general tenor conveys a

grave warning. From his place in the House of Lords he has delivered at least two most important speeches, the first soon after he took his place in that Assembly, the latter ** recently as July 31, when the Government announced the terms on which they had decided I to grant a Constitution to the Transvaal.

Some people, it is well known, take pleasure in prophesying evil; the raven's croak is their natural voice. It is not so, however, with Lord Milner. If he had been a pessimist he could never have lived through the arduous years from 1898 to 1904, and kept the firm faith which he always professed in the future of South Africa. It would be much more gratifying to him to believe that things were going well, as, indeed, they were, until this Government came into power and started their policy of meddling and muddling in South African affairs-in Natal as in the Transvaal. Lord Milner devoted most of his speech yesterday not to any specific act of the Government, such as the new Constitution, nor yet to any of the great problems of South Africa in which British interests have been jeopardised by those who now have the deciding voice at home. He holds that the most pressing danger of the moment in South Africa is disunion among the British Colonists, who seem ready on the very eve of the first electoral trial of strength to split into groups over merely personal differences, in face of a united Dutch party, which preaches incessantly a Dutch South Africa. But the danger of the moment at home is even greater, for it is the growth of what Lord Milner called the spirit of antinationalism. This is a subject to which we have often referred in these columns, since it is constantly breaking out in new forms and varieties, the only constant symptom being the inveterate belief that in any political quarrel one's own countrymen must be in the wrong.

An Englishman has only to cross the seas, and in the view of those who suffer from this strange "disease of opinion” he changes his nature as well as his sky. With the mind of the pro-Boer during the war everyone was painfully familiar. In some the malady reached the stage of delirium, and drove them to say that, unless the Boer cause triumphed, they would have to reconsider their belief in Providence. Perhaps the policy of the present Government may spare them such reconsideration, if they have not already performed that mental exercise, for to give away what we have won by hard fighting and vast sacrifices seems to be the ambition of a powerful section of Ministers. Lord Milner spoke of the extraordinary venom which is displayed against any South African who takes the British side in the conflict between British and Dutch ideals, between what was Milnerism and what Krugerism. The Little Englanders condemn him as one who must be "animated by the meanest sentiments, a tool of capitalists, & soulless, subservient creature, who can have no higher motive than the greed of gold." These are of the same kidney as the pessimists against whom the German Emperor was moved to lift up his voice in strong irritation a week or two ago, when he lamented that they would not relieve the unfortunate Fatherland of their presence. But the German anti-nationalistf are tyros compared with the British. Ourg are quite unapproachable for their mischievous persistence. How they filled the air with falsehoods about Chinese slavery is notorious - that was perhaps, their greatest achieve. ment, for it was a masterpiece of mendacious hypocrisy. Then & pro-Zulu agitation was started, which would have swollen to ten times its dimensions had a Unionist Government been in power, and the anti-nationalist Press grew eloquent over hypothetical outrages. The outcry against the punishment of the Egyptian villagers who set upon and murdered some British officers has hardly yet died away. Lord Cromer's measured warning to the Home Government of the growth of a fanatic anti-British agita. tion in Egypt is either derided, by these "anti-nationalists" or it is accepted as natural and worthy of all sympathy. The wrongs of India, again, are wringing their bosoms. Englishmen are accused of bleeding India tə death and of intensifying the poverty of her poorest classes. The Bengali agitators find ready champions here at home. Their seditious songs are carefully explained away as harmless ebullitions by a small but pertinacious group of Anglo-Indians, whose patronage of the Congress movement, and tolerance of the Swadeshi agitation, bid fair to cause really serious trouble in Bengal, where the success of their noisy clamour has alarmed the great Mohammedan section of the population. We do not believe that this anti-nationalism, as Lord Milner calls it, is popular with the mass of Englishmen, but it is unquestionably popular with the Radical pulpiteer, and with the Trade Union leaders, who are, for the most parti strongly anti-Imperialist. They carry their followers with them much further than the latter wish to go, and they do so the more light-heartedly, because of their exceedingly limited acquaintance with the affairs of any part of the Empire but their own. There will, as Lord Milner said, be a "tremendous rally" when these pernicious doctrines are pushed too far; but before the rally comes, mischief may be done which can only be eradicated very slowly and at enormous cost.
(“Daily Telegraph.")

div.p: THE KHEDIVE.
TANTAH AGRICULTURAL SHOW.

p.hi: The Khedive arrived at Ras el-Tin Palace from Montazah this morning, and held his first reception since his return from Borope, which was largely attended.. .. | Hassan Pasha Radwan, Mşdir of Gharbieh, in the name of the Mcudirieh, Ibrahim Pasha Said, on behalf of the Khedivial Agrion Littoral Society, and Mr. George Dominick, in the name of the Tantah Municipality, will be received by the Khedive at Ras el Tin palace, wben they will pray bim to preside at the opening of the Tantah Agric: Itural Show. We understand that his Highness will be graciously pleased to accept, and be will leave for Tantah by special train on Thursday, arriving at 10. 45 a.m, and will be accompanied by the Ministere. 1 His Highness will be received with a salute of 121 guns, and be will drive direct to Abmedi

Mosque to visit the tomb of Sidi Abmed el Bedawi. He will then proceed to the mosque which has been erected between Birket Beg house and the new criminal courts, after which he will launch on the show ground. The guests for the lunch number one hundred including the Ministers, the murders, members of the Khedivial Agricultural Society, Legislative Council, and Tantab Municipality. After dinner his Highness will attend a borse parade previously to opening the show,and be will leave for Alexandria at 4 p.m. An attendance of between fifty and sixty thousand persons is | expected. Order will be maintained by a force of 250 soldiers in addition to the police, and Mansfield Pasba will be in direct supervision.

Two banquets will be given by the Municipality of Tantah, to one of which one hundred Earopeans have been invited, and the other will be a wallimeh, of which 500 native notabilities will partake. Subscriptions have been collected for the show and include £300 from the Municipality and £350 from individual persons. Prince Omar Pasba Toussoun will be the guest of the Mondir.

LONDON, October 5. The Earl of Cromer will sail for Egypt on the 12th instant.

div.p: SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
IMPORTANT APPOINTMENT.

p.hi: The Egyptian Government has appointed Major Henri Gustave Joly de Lotbinière, D.8.0., R.E., to an important position in the Barvey Department under Captain H. G. Lyons. He belongs to a Huguenot Canadian family, and is a distinguished member of the Royal Engineers. He was born on the 10th March, 1868, and is the son of th: Hon. Sir Henry Gustave Joly de Lotbinière, K.C.M.G., V.C., (Canada), D. C. L., (France) L.L.D., Lieutenant Governor of British Columbia. He is the great-grandson of the last Marquis de Lotbinière and his father adopted his present Barname under a provincial statute in 1888. His mother is the daughter of Hammond Gowen, of Qeteo. The Major married in 1902 Mildred Louisa, daughter of C.E. Grenfell, and
he is thus a relation of the former Sirdar. He ,Jentered the army in 1888, Captain, 1889, and

Major, 19 0. He served in the North West frontier of India in 1897 98 (medal with three glasps). South Africa, 18o9 1902 (despatches twice brevet of Major, Queen's and King's medals' 5 clusps, D.S.O.)

div.p: THE SINAI PENINSULA.
THE BEDOUIN RAIDERS.

p.hi: The latest London papers to band confirm the news of the withdrawal of the Tarkish garrison of Khuzaima contained in our special service telegram of the 1st inst. We hear that Kusaima is well supplied with water, three springs, each of which gives birth to a small stream, affording a constant supply to the Bedouins of the district. An excellent well was found at El Aunt by the frontier commi-sion in the neighbourhood of the rains of an ancient castle constructed by the Crusaders to check Saracen raids. Several crosses were out in the walls of a rained chapel and fragments of a Greek inscription, dating perhaps from Byzan. tine times, in which the word "eteleatėsan" (thry) 'died' could be deciphered.

The Bedouin raiders mentioned in our last i8gne are described as well armed and equipped. They had martinis, swords, daggers, and pistols, and every man was accompanied by a spare camel. Their dress and appearance was very different from that of most of the Bedouins on the Egyptian side of the frontier, and while | the latter are in general poorly armed and equipped, the raiding party which Mr. Keeling encountered constituted a formidable fighting force of about 10 men. It appears to have been composed of contingents from the Ibn Jazi, Tarkish Barakat, and another tribe, and its object was the Hswa What olan with which the Arabs on the Ottoman side of the frontier have a feud.

div.p: SPLENDID -HOTELS OF EGYPT CO.

p.hi: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL.

The New Khedivial Hotel Alexandria has been undergoing a complete formation during the summer months in a very short space of time this magnificent hotel will be completely finished. Daring past year seventy-one new bedrooms, four bathrooms and other offices have been added and there are now one hundred and forty bedrooms. The new electric lift, by Stigler of Milan, goes, up to the top stories, and on the terrace of the third floor a large steam laundry has been set np. One of the greatest improvements has been the entire alteration of the kitchen arrangement. Hitherto the served was most awkward owing to the kitchen og situated ten minutes from the dining Now the old bar has been done away and part of it has been converted into an rance to the

kitchen which is now only two minutes from d from the restaurant. The remping, portion 1 of the old bar has been turned into a couriers' e dining room and the new bar has been placed 7. on the original site of the hotel bar on the

side facing the Z zivia Thes The new bed. e rooms have been furnished to ghout by h Maple and are got op most c ally. All r the wallpapers have been with the I greatest care and no pains have an spared to adorn each room with all the resources of European civilisation. On the 15th inst. the last workman will leave the hotel and the final touches are now being given to the grill. room, which is to take the place of the old terrace. The services of a first-class English cook have been engaged for the grill room, which will be used especially for soppers, A barman from the Waldorf Astoria Hotel at New York is arriving next week for the American bar. All the rooms of the botel have been retained 1 beforehand and every room will be engaged by the end of October. Seventy rooms are already taken for the 20 h ipat. | Mr. Frank Reinsperger, the new manager, who was for ten years at Shepheard's Hotel, bas been most energetic in his endeavours to have all the many improvements effected in the shortest possible time and he has been thoroughly successful in transforming the hotel so as to meet all the demands of its large clientèle.

div.p: THE LOST CITY OF MARIOUT,
EXCAVATION OF SAINT MENAS.

p.hi: The recent wonderful discovery of the long lost uity of Saint Menas in the wilds of the Mariont desert bas aroused great interest throughout enlightened Barope, for although it was known that this ancient city did exist, and that its site was only a few miles from Alexandria, all attempts to discover it whereabouts had been fruitless. Before the Christian Era the city had been a central point for the trade and caravan routes from Alexandria to Cyrene and the Oasis of Ammon and from central Egypt to the North West, but it is chiefly known to fame for the extraordinary sapotity, which it subsequently obtained owing to the exoja tion of Mena, an officer in the army, son of a Governor of a province of Afrios, who suffered martyrdom under Diocletian. His body was buried there and a Chorob was built to mark the spot. At the end of the fourth century a magnificent basilion was adopted in the reign of Arcadius and became a great resting place for pilgrims and travellers on their way from Alexandria to Nitria. A description is extant by an Arab geographer, who describes the Church of St. Mona as still standing, apparently, to an opinjared condition. | The date at which this description should be placed is probably between the early part of the eleventh and the early part of the fourteenth century, i.e. subsequent to the great destruction of churches in Egypt by the Caliph Hakim, when thirty thousand charges are said to have been ruined in Syria and Egypt. Since that date the old city bas atterley disappeared from history and Sir Massie Blom field in the Bulletin of the Alexandria Arobæological Society for 1904 stated that it is believed that the site was known to the Bedouins, and he adde?:

"It seems to me that the identification of this site with the assiótance of the Coast Guard authorities would be a suitable one on which to expend some portion of the funds of the Arcbæological Society." Bat the honour of the discovery of this long-lost city belongs to two German arcbæologists, the Rev. C. M. Kaufmann and Mr. J.C.B. Falls who alighted on the ruins on June 7, 1905. They have now compiled an account of their excavations | daring their first campaign, from November, 1905, to June, 1906. The work has just been published at Cairo, and is on sale at Diemer's Library (79.6d.). It is well printed and illustrated with 54 autotypes, which give the reader an excellent idea of the comprehensive obaracter of the work of excavation and of the mapy and various artistic finds that have been the outcome of these excavations. This book, which is dedicated by the authors to Schiess Pasha, gives a most interesting account of the discovery of one of the greatest arobæo. logical mysteries in Egypt, and should be read | by all who take an intelligent interest in the (ancient history of this country. The record of their work is carried on optil last Jode. Since then the Rev. C. M. Kaufmann and Ma Falls have excavated the building connected with the basilica of Arcading, the principal baptistry of the city, a part of the north cemetery with its basilios, and a small track of the recently discovered south cemetery. Work is now being carried on in the ancient Koinobiont. Ia Mense City all the principal buildings and churches are several metres underground and the work is of greatly difficulty. Some fifty cisterns have been discovered, and some of these have been excavated. For centuries no water has been obtainable at Karm Aba Mioa, except daring the winter months, and the water has to be supplied by a camel caravan from a village four miles away.

THE MONEY FAMINE. Within the next nine days £1,700 000 are expected to arrive at Alexandria from London, and this with the payment of the dividend on the Privileged Debt on the 15th inst. will considerably alleviate the stringency.
CORPORATION OF WESTERN
EGYPT

Very satisfactory samples of Abbasi Afifi and Yanovitz cotton grown on the lands watered by the now bored boles at Khargeh have been received by the Corporation of Western Egypt. The Ashmoon cotton was planted rather late, and is not yet ready for picking. The lands upon which most of the amp referred to was grown had never been activated or watered before. Very good samples of the wheat and barley of the winter crop are also to bapd,
LAND BANK OF EGYPT.

It will be remembered that at the extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Land Bank of Egypt, which was held in | Alexandria on September 8, the creation of a further £2,500,000 of debentures was authorised, making the total authorised £5,000,000. The amount at present issued is £1,000,000 in 50,000 three add-a-half percent. bonds of 500f. (£20), and a further issue of 90,000 four per cént. bonds of 500f. each will shortly be made. The fall details of this issue will be found in the financial portion of to-day's issue.

div.p: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.

p.hi: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex.
pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in spirit of fair play to all, to permit within certain necessary limits free discussion.
THE "TIMES" ARTICLE.
"AL MINBAR'S” REPLY.
To thE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Dear Sir.-I. "The Times" of the 18th alt.
letter appeared under the heading, "The Situation in Egypt" signed by "Phylax" which contained the following passage :--

"A new journal' belonging to the National party has made its appearance under the name of the "Minbar," or "Palpit," whose opening statement that although bolding bigb its duties to its country, Egypt, it holds still higher its doties to its religion, Islam, sounds

premonitory doto of its probable fatore tone-a dangerous one. It is now engaged in attacking Lord Cromer, and dison sses bis probable recall with a wealth of inventive faculty fally qualifying the journal even tbus early to proudly claim equality on the score of veracity with the 'Lewa' itself."

As the statements of "Phylax'' are erroneous, and not only calculated to create a talee impression amongst those of your compatriots who are acquainted with arabio, but also to do barm to the cause we desire to serve, might I crave the hospitality of your columns in order to place matters in their true light ? i "Al Miobar '' was started a few months ago by Mohamed Massoud Effendi and myself. with results which are already gratifying to as both-its sole proprietors. The policy of our paper, from its inception has been one of complete independence. We are under no bond or obligation to anyone, nor has any Power or Party the right to dictate to us the political views which they seek to propagate. Whilst laying no claim to infallibility, our purpose is to uphold the cause of justice, liberty and equality, to expose abuses and to lead our countrymen along the path of progress and enlightenment. In this sense, and in this sense alone, we are Nationaliste. We are likewise, and for similar reasons, PanIslamists.

Pan-Islamism we regard as a potent social toroe linking together and rallying under one standard of cooperation the various communities of Mohammedans scattered throughout the world, so that by cooperation they may unitedly assert their rightful claims amongst the nations of whom they are subjects. I know it has been alleged that therein larks a danger to Christendom. I grant that in the hands of unscrupulous and interested sectaries such may be the case. But "Al Minbar" never has, and so long as it remains ander its present management, never will support a selfish war of creeds or races.

My studies in English history and politics would have availed me little bad I not imbibed therefrom something of the Boglishman's sense of order. Oar paper, "The Tribune," as its nano implies, is intended to be the organ of the people, to voice their legitimate aspirations and to ventilate their real grievanc99; and I should like to kaow what fair-minded Englishman would blame as for that or find danger in. espousing such a noble cause. Criticism, be it. ever so honest, when ad verse is rarely relisbed. by those against whom it is directed. Bat criticism is as the breath of its nostrils to the poblio Press, and provided that personalities are not indulged in and bias excluded, nothing could be more salutary. Egypt especially needs it, for the Press in this country is the sole channel whereby public opinion can find expression and be justly ganged. Let me, finally, assure you, Sir, and those of your readers who deign to peruse these lines that we have no axe to grind, no personal ambition to gratify, save that of rendering disinterested service to the Egyptian nation by raising the tone of the vernacular journalism.
Thanking you by anticipation for the publication of this letter in your valuable column.I am, Sir,
Yours faithfully,
A. Hafiz & WAD. Editor-Proprietor of "Al-Miubar." Cairo, October 5.
THE BRINDISI MAIL.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "BGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, – You will have the British Colony with you if you demand a full, searching and independent inquiry into the causes of the non arrival of the "Isis” on Wednesday morning. There are rumours afloat, pamely, that the ship was known to be in an unseaworthy condition by reason of a partial disablement of her machinery before she left port, and it is now alleged that she has put into Zante with a broken shaft. Of course the company will be prepared with an exculpatory explanation, for that is the way with companies as with governments whenever they are called to account. But that will not eatis'y the publio. What they went, and you should insist upon their having, is an independent official investigation. To put a company upon its defence and to rest satisfied with whatever excuse it may choose to offer is like calling upon the accused to sit in judgment upon him. self. In the interests of public safety, in which I include both passengers and crew, the whole impartial truth, as it can alone be elicited by a commission of experts, should be made known, so that the blame, if blame there be, should rest upon the proper shoulders and dve precautions taken, should such be possible, against the recurrence of similar accidents.
But the breakdown of the "Isis" and its alleged navigation in spite of what bad happened, ed opens up wider issues. What is the exact I nature of the arrangements made between

Postal ships and the Postal authority regards delivery of mails? To be explicit, are the subsidia: d mail aten companies ander contract to perform voyages within a certain limit of time, au they liable to penalties in every instar failure from whatever cause! If a b case, contracts of the description, I mait ought to be declared pull and void on ground of public policy, ayo, for the humanity. Ships can be insured, somot! they are over ignored, so at, least Mr. Ch berlain used to tell as in the old days. If ship goes down the loss is merely a monotone. But in the event of loss of life, though sacb lives may be insured, on it said that any monetary indemnity can be regarded as an adequate solution 1. If any time clause exists such as I have suggested it oog to be cancelled forthwith by all civilized governments for the alternative of endangering that most precious and irreparable of possessions - dear human life-or committing
breach of contract entailing upon a me steamship Co. Heavy penalties is a temptation which a Captain may not be always able to resist and it is certainly one which should never be placed in his way.

In the above observations I have an id pothing about the inconvenience which delay of mails occasions to the business community of Egypt, let alone all the others farther east. This though important, is a consideration of minor moment to those I have argos. At the same time might it not be possible for Co. like the P. & 0. to have two ships ready to carry the mails from Brindisi to Port Said and vice versa so as thus to minimise the chances of delay! Yours truly,

DEATH OF COLONEL BLUNDELL.

Colonel Henry Blundell-Hollinshead-Blandell, formerly member of Parliament for the Ince Division of Lancashire, died yesterday week at his London residence, Stratton-stroot, Picosdilly, aged seventy-five years. The oldest son of the late Mr. R. B. Blondell'Hollinsbond. Blundell, of Deysbrook, was born in 1981, and we educated at Eton and at Christ Charoh, Oxford, graduating in 1854. Ho entered the Army as a second lieutenant in the Rifle Brigade in 1855, and was promoted lieutenant in the same year, and served in the Crimean Campaign after the fall of Sebastopol. He received the brevet of colonel in April, 1881, and in 1884-85 served with the Nilo! Expedition on the Staff as inspecting officer of the lines of communication, and afterwards as commandant at Dongola, being mentioned in despatches, and receiving for his services the medal with clasp and the Khedive's star. He was nominated & C.B. in Juno, 1887, and retired in January, 1889.,

p.hi: THE NEW CUNARDER.
The builders of the Mauretania, the newest liner of the Cunard Steamship Company, just floated, supply some interesting particulars regarding this monster vessel

Grey': Monument in Newcastle is 133ft. bigh. The captain's bridge on the liner from the keel is the same height, the flannels standing about half that height above the bridge. Twenty trains, each of twenty large tracks, would be required to carry the coal necessary for a voyage to New York and back, and the goal consumed on such a voyage would be sufficient to keep fires going in 3,000 workmen's house for a year. About 250 firemen and trimmers will | be necessary to deal with the coal.

If the funnels were placed one above another they would make a column 4 Oft. high, while the boilers were placed one above another they woáld form a column 547ft. big Two bondrei and fifty persons you'd lunch in one of the fun nels, each person being seatel comfortably at the table. Not cutting the pipes for steam and water connexions, there will be abant 1/4 miles of brags and steel tubes fitted to boilers, conden serg, eto. In the engine-room there will be nearly 600 tons of rotary machinery.

la the tarbines there will be three-quarters | of a million of blades, which, if placed end to end, would measure 110 miles. Two eletrico trains would pass esob other side by side in the condenser exhaust branch. The average length of the steam and feed pipes in the machinery rooms will be about a mile and a quarter. Some of the larger castings weigh about 38 tons each. The weight of the ingots from which the large drums were forged was 120 tops each. There will be 200 miles of electric cables in the hip.
The electric generating station of the ship is | larger than that which supplies Paisley, a town or 87,000.

div.p: THE REBELS OF THE YEMEN.

p.hi: In that masterpiece of English literature "The Life of Mahomet" by Washington Irving, the man who may be aptly described in his own words as "For all he did he had a reason, for all he said a word in season, and ever ready was to quote authorities for what he wrote" mich may be learned of the early history of the present inhabitants of Arabia Much information, as the author acknowledges was drawn from Gagnier's translation of the Arabian historian Abul 'feda, preserved in the Jesuite' convent of St. Isidor at Madrid,
The population of the Peninsula claims direct descent from Doctor, a great grandson of Shep, immortal for all time as one of those who sought the refuge of the Ark.

The kingdom of Yemen was founded by Yareb, one of bis song. A brother Jordan founded the kingdom of the Hedjız. It was into the latter family that Ishmael married. From the twelve song of the marriage the present prolific race really took their origin. In addition to carrying on the tradition or being wildmen like their progenitor "his band against every man, and every man's hand against him," they also retain to a certain extent some of the characteristics of their Jowieb ancestor pot only in their features, but also in their ability to accumulate flocks and
herde.
Gradually there grew ap & distinction between those who beld towns and castles" and those who "dwelt in tents."

of the former we are told that they occupied the fertile wadies or valleys, scattered here and there among the monntains, where these towns and castles were surrounded by vineyards and robards, groves of palm trees, fields of grain, and well stooked pastures. They were settled in their habits, devoting themselves to the cultivation on the soil and the breeding of cattle..

Others gave themselves up to commerce, having ports and cities along the Red Sea ; the southern shores of the Peninsula and the Half of Persia, and carrying on foreign trade by means of ships and caravane.

Such especially were the people of Yemen, or Arabis the Hs; þy, that land of spices, perfumes and frankincense; the Subans of the poets, the Sheba of the Sacred Scriptures. Bogaged as they were in the pursuits of peace, the inhabitants lost much of the original characteristics of the Arab, who, through the necessity of always having to defend his flocks and herds was familiar with arm; almost from infancy,
Yemen, osing to its wealth and accessibility, became the happy hunting ground for the adventurous invader who always carried on war on the principle of. "The spoils to the conqueror."

Since those days the various tribes have never been united except that they embraced the faith as expounded by Mahomet. Without any real say in the government of their country they have gradually seen the trade of the old days depart from their shores. The opening of the Suez Canal following after the discovery of the Cape route to India meant to them the loss of a great source of livelihood in the passage of the numerous Garavans through their territory.
At one time Mocha coffee was a commodity which meant much to the people of the Yemen.

Since the opening out of other sources of obtaining coffee, more especially the development of the West Indian Trade, even the táste for Mocha coffee has been lost. It is a well-known fact that people can acquire a taste and liking for an article really inferior to that which they may have at one time been accustomed. To-day most people who were offered pare Mocha coffee would not thank you for it, but still there is some demand for the article although we fear the supply is precarious, and what is often drunk as pare Mocha has seldom been grown in Arabia. Of late years the hold of the most recent conquerors,' the Turks, bas gradually been relaxed is the Yemen. Powerful chief: have been silently organizing until we have witnessed not only the commencement of a rebellion, but also what look almost like a successful attempt to throw off the Turkish yoke. .

The garrison drawn from the seventh army corps at Sanaa, the capital, a town of 75,000 inhabitants, beld ont against odds and under difficulties besides which the troubles and bardslips of the defenders of Ladysmith sink into insignificance. Such was the stubborn resistance of the Tark that, long before the arrival of Faizi Pasba, bastily sent out with reinforcements ill-equipped and devoid of an organized transport as the term is known to modern adjutant-general, cannibalism was rife. Indeed the first relief column to arrive considerably added to the distress, as before entering Saras much of their transport had been captured by the rebels. When the remnant of the garrison ultimately reached the coast and took ship at Hodeids, they presented a spectacle reminiscent of the rigours of the sieges of ancient times; haggard, giant human skeletons, smitten with sourvy, their bodies

div.p: CAPE TO CAIRO CINEMATOGRAPHED.

p.hi: Eight years ago, almost to the day, a Cape 1 Town contem; orary approved with moon blowing of trumpets the arrival in the Colony from London of a gentleman who was equipped with the latest style of cinematograph, with the intention of taking sorbe photographs.cf the different parts of South Africa. "He intende," stated the paper from which we qnote, 'manipulating the machine from a tramcar, and thus be enabled to produce in England and elsewhere the soevery from Cape Town to Wynberg, and in the same manner some of the best | views to be met with along the line from Cape | Town to Johannesburg. He has arranged with the railway authorities to have a special saloon car attached to an up-country train, and in | order not to miss any of the best soene", which will probably be passed through during the night, will return along the same route."

History is cariously silent as to the sequel. Whether the gentleman referred to succeeded in his enterprise deponent knoweth not, but certain it is that, if he did 1, his efforts and hardly be said to have set the Thames on fire. Let us hope that Mr. Charles Urban - a name t.miliar in men's months as household words were animated photography is concerned will be more successful. Ever on the lookout for something new, be bas bit apon the happy idea of "doing" the Dark Con| tinent from Cape Town to Cairo by means of the "Urbanora," and is now busily perfecting a scheme for sending out for expeditions to various parts of Africa, commencing simultaneously at Cape Town and at Cairo. It is a splendid notion, and one which, we feel sure, would have commended itself to the great heart of the late Mr. Rhodes, who doubtless would have been the first to perceive in it a most effective means of advertising Africa and its vast resources, with a view to stimulating an early and large influx of population from the United Kingdom.

"The object of the undertaking,” said Mr. Urban, in the course of conversation with a representative of the "African World," is to secure most comprehensive series of life motion pictures of the resources and industries already in operation in the territories en route, also general views of the character of the country. Special attention will be directed to accurately and advantageously depict, in detail, the agricultural, mining, stock-raising, rail-roading, and other transport facilities and their development in British South Africa, Uganda, Congo States, and the country between the Victoria Falls and Pa. abods, also throughout Egypt to Cairo. A living reproduction of these scenes would be of exceeding interest to investors, intending emigrante, touriste, sportsmen, and others, and of immense benefit to all Governments, companies, railways, hotels, and individuals concerned in the commercial expansion of Africa.

"No other means devised can do forcibly or convincingly pat Africa, or the possibilities of its developments, before the investing public of all countries as Urbanord. This we have demonstrated by our úndertakings on similar lines in depicting Canada, South America, Borneo, Australia, Switzerland, etc., with which pictures the public bas been fømiliarised daring the past three years, much to the benefit of those countries. The leaders of this expedition are picked men of experience, discretion, and resource, expert photographers and journalists, and are equal to the work of sach a large undertaking. Upon the termination of the expedition the results will be exhibited by Urbaora' at the Alhambra Theatre, London, as well as publicly shown in some eight hundred to a thousand theatres and places of entertainment throughout England, Continental Europe and America, besides other countries. An explanatory lecture tour by the leaders of the expedition upon their return will likewise be undertaken throughout Great Britain. In this way it is expected to keep the different sections of the African series exhibited consecutively before the public during the course of one year and after.

"Arrangements," went on Mr. Urban, "have been made with leading journals for descriptive illustrated articles, contributed by the leaders of the party, to appear during the progress of the exhibition and lecture tour. In order to facilitate the vast undertaking, we have decided to start four separate expeditions into different sections of Africa, within a few months of each other. This will enable us to reach the various Countries daring the most favourable climatic conditions (which is highly essential to our purposes), instead of open expedition undertaking the entire work from the Cape to Cairo."

Naturally, an undertaking of the kind would involve the expenditure of a very Large 80m of money, and we were scarcely surprised to hear that the Charles Urban Trading Company, Limited, invite the Gnancial 00operation of the principal South African companies for the soatbeth section of the work, and we make no doubt that when onoa the scheme is thoroughly understood by those chiefly concerned the necessary assistance will speedily be forthcoming. Already a good start has been made. Questioned on the subject

by our representative, Mr. Charles Urban | replied: "We are willing to contribute one-half of the expenses incurred on the trip, provided the other half of the cost is subscribed by the various companies and firms who would be benefited by the carrying out of oor project.
We are only asking cooperation from a few of stbe principal South African companies. We

want the proper assistance and facilities for our men in order that they may secure the best results." "You have 'worker Canada and Australia on similar lines already, have you pot, Mr. Urban ?'. Yes, and our source-& in

bore undertakings was due to the fact that we know how to produce a picture series which is novel, attractive, entertaining and instructive, containing advertising value without reflecting in the least from the general interest of the subject depicted. I am proud to say

p.hi: Mr. P. Brien, Accountant residing at 28 Third Street, Limoilou, Quebec, writer:

div.p: The fatigues entailed by my duties as accountant began to weaken my system about a year ago. I felt that I would not long be able to withstand the severe strain upon my nerves, as, a thing unknown to me before, I would long for office hours to be over in order to rest.

hi.hi: "I gradually grew weaker and a few months later my sight was Im. paired. I then broke down completely and was obliged to take my bed. I was also suffering from palpitation of the heart.

p.hi: "After a few weeks' treatment by a local physician, I was in the same critical condition and as the doctor held out no great prospects for me, I decided to experiment on myself.

div.p: "I took several remedies advertised as tonics, but did not derive any benefit.

hi.hi: "Peruna was then given a trial, and before I had taken it a week I felt my condition Improving. After a few weeks more had elapsed, during which time I followed the directions carefully, my shattered nervous system became firmer, my sight stronger and I hoped to be out soon again.

div.p: "My expectations were realized, for in three weeks I assumed my duties as accountant at the office.

p.hi: Peruna certainly worked wonders on my system, and for persons run. down from overwork, I believe it is the most efficacious tonic."

p.hi: REVUE COMMERCIALE

div.p: Cotons

p.hi: Ce que nous prê bios depuis une éternité s'est enfin réalisé : La baisse de l'américain est survenu de et il suffit de la confirmation des qne qres dégâts dont ont parlé les dépêches de la semaine dernière pour la prova quer. Ce D'est pas par simple esprit de vanité que Deus avons commencé avec ce préambule, mais notre but est de constater qu'à la suite de oe qui est arrivé pendant la huitaine, presque tous pour lecteurs ont fini par reconnaître que nous avions vu juste dans tout ce que nous avons écrit depuis quelque temps au sujet de la situation boutonnière. Ce n'est pas une mince satisfaction pour nous et cela efface l'amertume ressentie parfois à la suite de critiques injustes qui nous ont été adressées ' qasd votre opinion déplaisait a l'an on à l'autre. Ceci dit, passons à la revue de marobe.

div.p: Samedi ayant été jour férié, la reprise des affaires n'a eu lieu que lundi et comme début DOGS avons eu à enregistrer pour ladite matinée une avar ce nette de 11/32. Pour le lendemain, c'est une nouvelle hausse de 7/32 qui est venue s'orienter, la clôture ayant en lieu à 17 1/16, après que, comme maximum Nous avions pratiqué le cours de 17 18/32. Mercredi, le Novembre est monté à 17 15/32, mais comme fiable il s'est inscrit à 16 15/16.

La bourse dans les deux journées avait été faite par les nouvelles d'Amérique, tandis que la réaction n'a été que le résultat des attaques du parti de la baisse qui a réussi à entraver la marche en avant avec ses continuelles ventes. Dans tous les cas, au fond, il y avait une certaine fermeté et la preuve en est qu'hier, et malgré la baisse inattendue d'une cinquantaine de points dans la côte de New York, c'est à peine si le cours de Novembre était tombé pour un moment à 16 13/16 pour finir à 16 29/32.

Quant à la séance de ce jour, elle a été favorisée par la reprise de New York, et quoique le maximum de 17 3/16 n'ait pu être maintena, la semaine s'est terminée en baisse, quand même, sort la veille à la cote de 17 1/32.

Cela nous fait 17/32 de gagné pour la co maine, mais ce qui est encore mieux, c'est le revirement que l'on remarque dans la tendance: Le marché est franchement pour la beusse et si l'Amérique s'en être encore,nous pourrions bien avoir un saut agar important dans les prix. Aux cours actuels, il y a rapprochement sensible entre américain et égyptien, et se dernier ne pent dire qne gagner dans la faveur de la consommation ; du reste, la filature anglaise n'a pas trop regardé à la hausse et a e core fait quelques achats à livrer sur notre absorbé pendant la semaine qui vient de finir.

Constatons encore que le déport qui existait sar janvier dimitte chaque jour davantage et que très probablement, d'ici peu de temps, nous verrons tous les mois à doigtés s'établir en report, comme cela est invariablement nabi ude sur notre marché. pour revenir à la situation générale de l'er
il est naturellement difficile, dans l'excitation du moment, de se faire une opinion I want à l'avenir ; mais ce qne l'on peut dire, nast qu'en Amérique le mouvements mble
voir avoir une durée assez longue encore. ca effet, on parle d'un corner sur octobre et poème le découvert est colossal et que la

p.hi: msin d'auvre pot r faire la oneillette n'abonde par, une pareille combinaison rentre dans le domaine du possible. Hidope ce que l'on dit se vérifie, il va de soi que le coton égyptien ne pourra qu'en profiter.

div.p: Le resserrement d'argent qui a contribué quelque peu à calmer l'ardeur de nos haussiers perrine toujours, mais les jours de cette petite orise sont comptés. Il y a beaucoup d'or en route et d'ici au 15 courant toute trace de la pénurie actuelle aura disparu.

p.hi: On dit que la hausse de l'Américain profite largement à l'Egypte; ce n'est pas une mauvaise nouvelle que nous donnons 1, et tout ce que nous souhaitons c'est que le fait soit vrai, osr de cette sorte, outre le bénéfice indirect que le pays retire de l'amélioration dont l'égyptien profite par rieubet, il y aurait de ce chef bestcoup d'argent qui rentrerait dane les poches de nos spéculateurs.

div.p: Les avis de la récolte sont moins bons qu'ils ne l'étaient, il y a quelque temps, mais comme nos lecteurs le verront par le Résumé de Septembre de la Produce Association que nous

p.hi: reproduisons plus loin, la récolte est considérée Ignan même bien supérieure à celle de l'année

passée. A remarquer toutefois qu'il y a en des dégâts et que telle qu'elle est représentée aujourd'hui, elle ne peut plus être cette record crop dont parle un des rapports de Ministère des Travaux Publics.

div.p: Ona iran guré ces jours-ci les affaires sur

vembre 1907 en commerçant par le cours de 15 11/16, pour tomber ensuite à 15 5/8, Le déport pour la récolte 1907 8 est assez sensible pour faire croire que très probablement la prochaine campagne, dans ces conditions, attirera l'attention de la filature continentale qui avait déjà montré des dispositions à acheter pour novembre 1997 et janvier 1908. Dans tous les cas, cela fournit une base à l'export

p.hi: tion et la
régulation qui est en train de

div.p: s'amuser à acheter du mars 1906 et à vendre de novembre 1907 ferait bien de se modérer.

Le ma ebé do disponible a été rétif pendant | la semaine, groʻqne ces deux derniers jours il y sit en un pen de ralentisse aut cause de la situation financière de la place. Les prix cependant, et malgré les fortes recettes, se maintiennent assez bien, la baisse de la semaine n'étant que de 1/2 tallari pour le Good Mit Afifi et de 3/s pour les provenances Haute Betype. En son me, la demande est benne.
En fait d'exporta on, nous n'avons eu que helles 13,100 pour la rousine, contre 13,400 l'anr de dernière, mis il est à croire que la
emaine prochaine offrira ample compensation, le relevé des embarquements devant comprendre les arriérés de cette semaine restés en suspens et qui sont importante.

A ce popor, relevons qu'une ligne santée Hans la composition de notre dernière revue a faersé les cb ft es que nous avions donnés en me expéditions de l'année passée. Il faudrait lire : Embarquements Oe-obre 60,000 balls, Novembre 130,000 billes, total pour les deux mois 19.000 bailes
Liverpool a été assez actif pour les égyptiens disponibles, le chiffre des ventes ayant augmenté d'une façon maqu née ce jours derniers.
Pour ce qui est des prix, il y a de la bause is it, 1/16 sur le spot coté à 9 9/16 pour le folly good fair.
Quant aux futurs ils ont encore été mieux rangés, la valeur de jour de l'Octobre étant de 9 1'/64 et celle du nov. de 8 58, 64.

p.hi: Les Américains disponibles ont aussi été plus animés, mais les affaires sont toujours entravées par la rareté du choix. Eo attendant,

div.p: sur la côte, il y a à relever une amélioration de 48 points pour le spot qui vaut 6.14, tandis que les futurs s'inscrivent à 583, soit en basse de 76 points, tant pour l'Octobre Novembre, I que pour le Janvier Février.

p.hi: P8-00 nous informe a la dernière beure et vous donnons la nouvelle à titre de simple Renseignement, que les cotons provenant des réceptions Anot ont été offerte au pair avec le Novembre.--Nous nous attendions bien i ola pour le 22 Octobre, mais pas pour le 5!!
Graines de Coton Les arrivages sont réguliers, mais pas encore suffisants pour les besoins at els et tout astarellement cela contribue à la fermeté des prix.
Le cours de jour da disponible est de P.T. 63.1/2.
Les exportations sont fortes et promettent d'être satisfaisantes pour tout le mois.

Le marché des contrats est ferme et finit même en bausse & P.T. 63 3/4 pour ** 8 mois, mais la spéculation est toujours réservée et les affaires en général pont limitées aux vérations des exportateurs qui achètent quand ils ont à

couvrir quelques ventes, pour l'Europe. | L'Angleterre se montre froide, mais au fond elle ne fait qu'acheter tout tranquillement. Elle ne se laisse pas intrafor sur les échéant ces éloignées, car la spéculation manque chez nous pour lui forcer la main, mais pour les em baraquements rapprochés elle y met le prix. Les dernières cotes de Hall sont de £6.11.3 première qui zsine Octobre, £6 7/6 pour tout Octobre et £ 6 8/9 pour les 3 mois.

div.p: Feve. Nalité complète et cours absolument nomi

p.hi: DAOX.
ALEXANDRIA GENERAL PRODUCE
ASSOCIATION
RÉSUMÉ DES RÉPONSES REÇUES EN
SEPTEMBRE 1906

div.p: Pendant la première moitié de Septembre, les conditions atmosphériques ont été assez favorables sex cotonniers, mais pendant les derniers jours de mois, on a constaté de gros ques changemente de température et des boite trop fraises, accompagnée de quelques bouil. lards

p.hi: Ces circonstances n'ont pas été sans boire aux altares; mais leur action été très inégal lière, et landis que plusieurs localités sont demeurées indemnes, d'autres ont souffert com me retard dans la cueillette et comme ebote d'une partie des noix de la dernière production,

div.p: Aussi, les dégâts sont diversement évalués; toutefois, la généralité de dos correspondants sont toujours d'avis que la récolte, dans son ensemble, dépasse sensiblement celle de 1905.
Il n'a pas été question des vers, et l'exa abonde partout.
L'égrensgo donne jusqu'à présent des rendements très irréguliers, et à peu près comme l'année passée.
Dans la Haute Egypte, malgré la domination de l'agréage, on espère obtenir une récolte égale & la précédente.

CHRONIQUE FINANCIÈRE

div.p: Alexandria, le 5 Octobre Notre maroobé des valeurs, encouragé d'un | côté par le hauria des bons et de l'autre

p.hi: par les ohata da de ouvert, débuté lundi par une reprise générale et importante. Des le lendemain, malheureusement après une ouverture pleine d'entrain et de promesses, le relèvement de taux d'escompte 4 1/8 % ast velle rappeler à la spéculation que la crise financière névisuait encore et a déterminé ave réaction , dans l'ensemble la côte n'en est pas moins restée forme et en bosse partielle. Mercredi les affaires ont eu plus d'ampleur et se sont limitées sa Comptoir sur lequel il s'est produit un mouvement, consionné sans doute par la prochaine assemblée générale et l'accaparement des titres qui se est la conséquence habituelle. Hier enfin la nouvelle s'est confirmée que l'argent faisait défaut sur place et que les bananer refusent de faire des AYDOH sur titres.

Cette disette de numéraire n'est pas non velle pour l'Egypte. On peut dire que chaque Année à la même époque elle se produit avec plus ou moins d'intensité, mais d'ordinaire on la sent venir; comme l'orage elle des signes Avant contenons ; les banques se montrent plus difficiles dans leurs avancent rar titres, les te porta atteignent des prix élevés, le liquida tions deviennent plus laborieuses. Cette année où la prise est arrivé à l'improviste: de jour au lendemain les banques ont refusé d'avancer sur titres et quelques unes thème ont renvoyé le payement de leurs chèques à landi; asoone liquidation laborieuse a fait pressentir l'ouragan. Ce serait, ce que l'on prétend du moins, la hausse de coton qui nous aurait valu cette surprise. Les établissements finan. niers assurent, en effet, qu'ils avaient les dis. possibilités ordinaires pour faire face aux demandes d'argent de l'intérieur, mais cette hausse de coton tenté un si grand nombre d'agriculteurs à la fois qu'il y a eu vente en masse de coton, circonstance imprévus qui occasionné un drainage d'or formidable. La raison qui avait ameuté la hausse des valeurs luodi dernier s'est donc trouvé être en même temps la cause indirecte de leur réaction par la pénurie monétaire qu'elle a créée sur place.

Fait digne de remarque, cette épreuve qui aurait pa jeter le panique dans la corbeille des valeurs, D's produit qu'une réaction à peine sensible. Elle a démontré que la situation est 1sb absolument aside, les positions peu sarobargées | et les détenteurs actuels assez forts en général pour attendre des temps meilleurs.

div.p: Il faut avouer, cependant, que la gêne mode taire n'est pas encore sur son déclin. Bien qu'en effet le taux d'escompte ait été bien réduit de nouveau à 4 3/8 % sous voyons la proportion de la réserve avec les engagement de la Barque en Angleterre diminuer de 42 7/8 % I 88 1/8 % Le Consolide Anglais d'avance de 86 1/2 X 86 5,8. Quantaox valeurs égyptiennes, elles font preuve d'un soutien de bon augure à la boar e de Londres : la National

p.hi: Bank gagne même 1/4 de livre à 26 7/8. | A Paris, au contraire, il y a baisse en général. La Poste Fear çsise, réactionnel à 96.05. Ea bausse, il n'y a que les options de Suet à 4460 et la Land Bank of Egypt á 280. Les autres valeurs égyptiennes sont en réaction plus ou

Comme résultat de la semaine, on peut dire que comme ensemble nous restons au même point que vendredi passé. Va tiers des valeurs environ sont en brousse, un tiers en baisse et un tiers demeurent stationnaires. La flotustions i les plus remarquables sont : la soste,

div.p: Delta Light qui gagne 1/8, la dividende Tram 1 wye 6 fracos, la Bebers 1/8, les Markets
pence, mais surtout la Nile Land qui s'avance de 14 13/16 à 15 1/8 et la part de fondateur Comptoir de 43 44 livre ; & la baisse, la Dei a qui perd 1/8, la Deferred Delta 1/8, et la Delta Land 1/9.

Il nous revient que le gouvernement égyptien n'est pas étranger au soutien actuel des cours. A peine la disette d'or lui stelle été sonde qu'il s'est empressé aujourd'hui même de mettre provisoirement à la disposition de

p.hi: moins sensible.
| JOINT SYSTÈME BÜHNE pour manchons de tuyaux d'eau et de gaz.

div.p: Manchon d'un tuyau de 390 mm de diamètre rendu étanche par laine de plomb Baume et sunt
une pression de 20 Atmospheres.
ce vide, puis on mata le plomb sont d'abord une tresse de
fondu la laine du
système de raccord étanche

p.hi: e suit :

div.p: Jusqu'à présent on assemblait les manchons de tuyaux en y introduisant tout d'abord une tresse de chanvre et en coulant du plomb dans la partie restée vide, puis on mata le plomb coulé.

Notre nouveau système de raccord étanche se comporte tout autrement. Nous employons au lieu de plomb fondu la laine du plomb brevetée en tres es de 1 m. de longueur et pesant t ou 1 kilo, suivant les manchons, et procédons comme suit :

Après avoir tout d'abord introduit et comprimé la tresse de chanvre, on prend une tresse de laine de plomb ou une partie seulement de la tresse, selon la force du joint, on l'enroule autour du tuyau et on ls mato fortement dans le manchon, on répète l'opération jusqu'à ce que le manchon soit complètement plein et bien maté. Par le fait que le matage commence déjà au fond du manebos ea. d. directement sur la tresse de chanvre, la laine de plomb se transforme en une masse homogène, au moyen de laquelle on réalise non seulement une étanchéité parfaite, mais encore résistance beaucoup plus considérable qu'auparavant.

Des essais de notre nouveau système de raccordement étanche ont été faite non seulement dans nos wines, mais aussi en beaucoup de villes qui en font l'étude à différents points de vue. Ainsi nous avons réalisé des joints de tuyaux de 300 et 450 mm de diamètre d'après notre procédé et soumis ces joints pendant des semaines à une pression constante de 20 atmosphères sa gne le record cédât, on réunit également bout bout 4 tuyaux de 100 mm de diamètre d'après notre procédé ; on plaça les deux extrémités sur deux supports de telle sorte que la partie intermédiaire ne fût pas soutenue. On ne constata ainsi qu'une flexion, Par contre un essai analogue avec des joints en plomb fondu causa une flexion considérable.
1 est ainsi démontré qu'avec notre procédé on obtient un joint bien étanche et une résistance mécanique bien plus grande qu'autrefois.
Notre nouveau procédé de raccordement étanche offre en outre l'immense avantage de permettre de travailler par tous les temps et sans nécessiter la mise à ses des manchons.
Outre ces énormes avantages techniques, notre procédé présente vis à vis des anciens procédés encore d'autres

L'appareil encombrant pour le coulage du plomb est supprimé, e aree lui tout le combustible tel que b a I coke, la perte de plomb à la coulée est méritée, on supprime de même le sable, la main ere de montage des têtes I de manchons et la main d'entrée de coulage.
Dans notre procédé il ne faut plus que des mateurs.
Il s'ensuit que notre méthode rend le travail plus économique que l'ancien procédé, sans parler des avantages concernant l'hygiène. AUG. BÜHNE & Co.,

La souscription l'émission des 90.000 obligations Land Bank of Bayot s'ouvre lundi prochain, 8 octobre, et se elotore le même joer. Ce sont des obligations bypothéonira de 600 frs, de type 4 %; le taux d'intérêt et de 30 franon set de tout impôt et les coupons sem er triels sont payable lo ler janvier, et le ler juillet de bagoë année. Les titres sont reme boursables à 500 france par voie de tirage annuels na plus tard les 75 ans. Le prix d'émie sion est de 45 france, payables 100 francos en arrivant et le solde à la répartition qui sera lieu de 16 au 20 courant. Pour l'Egypte, le souscriptions seront règnes à la National Bank
Alexandrie et au Caire.

p.hi: Mr. Mack, membro da Board de Londres de 'Egyptian Land and General Trust, se trouve sa Caire depuis une dizaine de jours. Il est, comme on le sait par le rapport de cette société, délégué en Egypte pour prendre en mains la direction de la société et procéder la vente des terrains dont la cession serait jagte opportune. Mr. Monk n'a pas reçu de Londres de communications apostles as sujet de l'appel de fonds dont on avait parlé.

La Société Générale de Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte rappelle à ses obligations qu'au moment de l'échange den obligation, les porteurs peuvent demander l'échange pur et simple on l'échange avec l'estampille donnant droit à un coupon annuel de 8 franos pendant 3 ans, payable par semestre. L'option pour l'estampille prend fin le 31 décembre 1906. Pour les actions, une nouvelle sera remise en bobine de trois anciennes. Les porteurs des titres, notions et obligatione, per vent dès maintenant les déposer contre un reçu provisoire changer ultérieurement contre les nouveaux titres, en Caire, au siège de la société, a l'Anglo Egyptian Bank ou à la National Back at & Alexandrie à l'agence de Crédit Lyonnais

A propos de la hausse récente de la Nile Land, nous croyons intéressant de publier les renseignements suivants : Le capital de cette société est de LE 300.000, représenté par 60,000 actions de LB 5. dont 45,000 avaient été allouées à M. Ch. Bacos, lors de la formation de la compagnie, en bobange de son ap por: de 4.687 feddans de terrains dans la Haute Egypte et ailleurs, terrains grevés de LB 106,000 d'hypothèque nes at dettes dont le société a assumé la obergo. Les 45.000 notions de M. Bacos pourront, dès le 13 octobre courant, aux termes des statuts, être négociées par leur propriétaire. Ce ne sont dono plas 15.000 Nile Land qu'il y aura sur le marché, mais bien 60.000. Il existe, en outre, 3000 parts de fondateurs dont le prix nominal est de 85 LB.
Comme précédemment, DODS avons la conviction que nos valeurs for cières sont appelées

profiter largement de prochain courant de hausse. L'événement nous a amplement donné raison l'année passée et il n'y a pas de motif pour qu'il n'en soit pas de même cette année ci. Sans doute les titres qui ont déjà escompte presque tout l'avenir par une hausse proportionnelle doivent être écartés, mais il en est d'autres pour lesquels rien et escompté et dont la plus-value actuelle ne représente guère que le bénéfice des opérations réalisées. C'est

p.hi: SUDAN GOVERNMENT
DISPOSAL OP BUILDING SITES
AT PORT SUDAN

div.p: The Sudan Government will shortly dispose by Tender of about 400 Building Sites at Port Sudan.
The sites will be Leasehold held at Annual Rents on Building Lease for Eighty Years from 1st January, 1907. Rents will be payable only from the date of acceptance of Tender.
The Lease will be Perpetually Renewable at Revised Rents fixed in default of Agreement by Arbitration at the end of each term of years.
In fixing the revised rents the value of Buildings erected by Lessees will Not be regarded as a ground for Increase of Rent

Example: If a plot is leased for a term of | 80 years from Ist January 1907 then on the expiration of that term the Lessee will have a right (subject to observance of his covenant eye) to obtain a fresh lease for a further period of 80 years at a revised rent, and so on in perpetuity. The revised rent will be calculated on the value the site would bear if it were vacant building lands.

p.hi: Offers are invited by Premiums for the Purchase of the above mentioned leasehold sites.

div.p: All offers must be made by Tender, on the forms issued by the Sudan Government, and must be received at Khartoum not later than Ist January 1907.

Particulars of the sites offered, Plan of the Town, Conditions of Tender and Sale, Forin of Tender, specimen Form of Lease, ete., will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to inspection at the following places during the usual business hours: Khartoum : *Office of Director of Agricul
ture and Lands (T) and Office of Governor
of Khartoum Province, Cairo: *Office of Sudan Agent (T). Port Sudan: Office of Inspector (Govern
ment Office) (T). Suakin: Office of Governor of Red Sea
Province. El Damer: Office of Governor of Berber
Province. Atbara : Office of Director of Railways, Alexandria : Office of Mr. Macpherson Grant. Port Said : Office of Dixon Bey, War Office
Representative London : *Office of Col. Western, Broadway
Chambers, Westminster, and the Sudan
Court, Imperial Institute. Suez: Office of Capt. Falloner, War Office

Representative. For the convenience of intending purchasers the Conditions of Tender and Sale have been translated into Arabie and French and copies of the translations into either language will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. per copy at the Offices in the above list which are distinguished by a capital T.
Further information will be obtainable after the publication of the above-mentioned documents on application in writing to The Director of Agriculture and Lands Khartoum

div.p: GOUVERNEMENT DU SOUDAN

p.hi: Concessions de Terrains a Batir
a Port-Soudan

div.p: AVIS Le Gouvernement du Soudan va prochainement disposer, par voie d'adjudication d'en viron 400 parcelles de terrains « bâtir à PortSoudan.

Les dites parcelles seront données à bail emphytéotique, pour une durée de 80 années à partir du 1er Janvier 1907, moyennant loyer annuel, a charge pour le locataire de bâtir. Le loyer ne sera payable qu'à partir de la date de l'acceptation de l'offre.
les baux seront renouvelables à perpétuite moyennant un loyer variable fixé à la fin de chaque terme, soit d'accord, soit par arbitrage.
En fixant le nouveau loyer, la valeur des bâtiments élevés par le locataire ne sera pas considérée comme un motif d'augmenta ion de loyer.

EXEMPLE: Si une parcelle de terrain est louée pour une durée de 80 années à partir du ler Janvier 1907. Dans ce cas, « l'expiration de ce délai, le locataire aura un droit (& condition d'observer les conditions du bail) d'obtenir un nouveau bail pour une nouvelle période de 80 années, moyennant un loyer modifié, et ainsi perpétuite.

p.hi: Le loyer modifié sera calculé sur la valeur du terrain, s'il était libre de construction,

div.p: Des offres sont demandées pour les baux emphytéotique, dont s'agit; ces offres devront mentionner la prime que le soumissionaire est disposé à payer au comptant en sus des loyers annuels établis pour chacun des lots. La dite prime devra être payée en un seul versement à la signature du contrat de bail.
Toutes offres doivent être faites par soumis sion, sur les formules dressées par le Gouverne ment du Soudan, et doivent être reçues * Khartoum avant le ler Janvier 1907.

Le détail des terrains offerts, le plan de la ville, les conditions de l'adjudication et de la concession, la formule de soumission, spécifica tion du bail, seront à la disposition du Public la partir du ler Octobre 1906, aux lieux ci-après
indiqués, durant les heures de bureau. 1 Khartoum*-Bureau du Directeur de l'A
grieulture et des Terrains (T) et bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Khartoum.
Le Caire Bureau de l'agent du Gouverne ment du Soudan (T).
Port Soudan Bureau de l'Inspecteur (Bu reau du Gouvernement (T).
Souakim Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province et de la Mer Rouge
Wadi Halfs Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Halfa
El-Damer-Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Berber.
Atbara Bureau du Directeur du Chemin de Fer.
Alexandrie -Bureau de Mr. Macpherson Grant.
Port-Sand-Bureau de F. Dixon bey, Repree sentant du Ministère de la Guerre.
Londres Bureau de Colonel Western. Broadway Chambers, Westminster et le Soudan Court, Imperial Institute
Suez-Bureau du Capitaine Falconer, Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.

Pour la commodité des acheteurs éventuels, les conditions d'adjudication et de concession, ont été traduites en arabe et en français et des copies de ces traductions, dans les deux langues, peuvent être obtenues à partir du ler Octobre 1906, moyennant payement de P.T. 5 par copie, aux bureaux mentionnés dans la liste ci-dessus, qui sont suivis d'une lettre majuscule T.

Des informations supplémentaires peuvent être obtenues après publications des documents ci-dessus mentionnés, moyennant demande (erite adressée au Directeur de l'Agriculture et des Terrains, à Khartoum.
Aux bureaux marqués d'une astérisque, copies les documents pourront être obtenues à partir de 12 Detobre 1906, moyennant payement de P.I. Sou un helling par copie.
